DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Lawyer: Noriega Will Die Rather Than Be Captured
Eds: INSERTS one graf after 7th graf, `Takiff questioned ...' with trial judge comments. ADDS two grafs with comments from Panamanian exile.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega said today the Panamanian leader would die rather than surrender to U.S. forces sent to bring him to this country to face drug charges. Panamanian exiles here celebrated the U.S. attack. Noriega was indicted on federal drug charges in Miami and in Tampa in 1988. Attorney Raymond Takiff said he talked with the general Monday evening. ``We discussed various things, including this very real possibility (of U.S. military action),'' the Miami lawyer said in a telephone interview. The attorney said he had planned to fly to Panama City this evening to meet with Noriega. This morning, he spoke with members of the general's staff who didn't know his whereabouts. ``He's a fighter,'' Takiff said. ``I feel unhappily secure in my belief that he will be killed, he will not be captured. Should that occur, the truth will never come out.'' Takiff questioned news accounts that Noriega had declared war on the United States, which he described as ``just some more propaganda that's come across again out of context.'' U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler, assigned as the trial judge in the Miami indictment, said today: ``If General Noriega is apprehended and brought here for trial, he would be given the same treatment as any other person accused of a crime _ no more, no less. All his rights will be protected.'' Also closely following events were members of Miami's Panamanian exile community, including Luis Endara, cousin of Guillermo Endara, who won the country's May election but was blocked by Noriega from taking power. Guillermo Endara declared himself president shortly after the U.S. military action began. ``I can assure you 99.99 percent of all Panamanians are up. I know of at least five parties going on (in Miami),'' Luis Endara said in an early-morning telephone interview. He added that he had been in telephone contact with Panama. ``Many of the opposition's key people have taken refuge in safe places since we had reports way back from before the elections of May that the dignity brigades (armed citizens who support Noriega) had lists of key opposition people to attack should something like this happen,'' he said. Convinced the military action would be a success, Luis Endara predicted many Panamanians living in this country would return to their homeland afterward. ``Exiles will probably return to Panama once everything is back to normality,'' he said. ``We will probably see for the first time an emigration back to a country that has been liberated.'' Another Panamanian in Miami said that if Noriega is captured, he will have to ``face all the things that he has done to the Panamanian people.'' ``I think he owes to the Panamanians many things and this is the first thing we have to face,'' said Aurelio Barria, founder of the National Civic Crusade in Panama. ``We would like to find the truth of all the cases pending and try him in Panama.''
